Details: Both outputs address identical core objectives: analyzing SSIS package conversion to Python with focus on ETL operations, data warehouse functionality, and employee data processing. Key semantic alignments include: (1) Both identify the package as 'Employee_Data_Warehouse' ETL pipeline, (2) Both assess conversion accuracy across control flow tasks, data flow components, and script tasks, (3) Both highlight similar discrepancies (error handling granularity, logging mechanisms, performance considerations), (4) Both provide optimization suggestions (parallel processing, memory management, enhanced logging), (5) Both conclude with positive overall assessment and similar recommendations. Minor semantic differences: Summary_Analyzer emphasizes 'well-optimized conversion' while Detailed_Analyzer focuses on 'completeness and accuracy'. Scoring rationale: High alignment on intent and conclusions with minor emphasis variations.

Significant structural differences identified: Summary_Analyzer uses descriptive section headers (Summary, Conversion Accuracy, Discrepancies and Issues, Optimization Suggestions, Overall Assessment, Recommendations) in flowing narrative format. Detailed_Analyzer employs numbered sections (1. Summary, 2. Conversion Accuracy, etc.) with detailed subsections and bullet points. Flow similarities: Both follow logical progression from overview to detailed analysis to recommendations. Structural differences: (1) Summary_Analyzer uses paragraph format throughout, (2) Detailed_Analyzer includes tabular complexity metrics (lines 25-35), (3) Detailed_Analyzer provides more granular subsections within each major section, (4) Summary_Analyzer integrates cost information inline, Detailed_Analyzer separates it as distinct section. Scoring rationale: Same logical flow but fundamentally different presentation structures.
